body_html:
@ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> are you passing the sequence_length= argument to the static rnn call?
…
On Thu, Apr 6, 2017 at 2:43 AM, Vlad Firoiu ***@***.***> wrote: @ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> I think it might work in 0.10/0.11, but I don't remember for sure. I just ended up writing my own unroller: def rnn(cell, inputs, initial_state): inputs = tf.unpack(inputs, axis=1) outputs = [] state = initial_state for input_ in inputs: output, state = cell(input_, state) outputs.append(output) outputs = tf.pack(outputs, axis=1) return outputs, state This assumes the time axis is 1. In more recent tensorflow versions, [un]pack has been renamed to [un]stack. — You are receiving this because you were mentioned. body_text:
@ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> are you passing the
sequence_length= argument to the static rnn call?
…
On Thu, Apr 6, 2017 at 2:43 AM, Vlad Firoiu ***@***.***> wrote:
 @ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> I think it might work in
 0.10/0.11, but I don't remember for sure. I just ended up writing my own
 unroller:

 def rnn(cell, inputs, initial_state):
   inputs = tf.unpack(inputs, axis=1)
   outputs = []
   state = initial_state
   for input_ in inputs:
     output, state = cell(input_, state)
     outputs.append(output)
   outputs = tf.pack(outputs, axis=1)
   return outputs, state

 This assumes the time axis is 1. In more recent tensorflow versions,
 [un]pack has been renamed to [un]stack.

 —
 You are receiving this because you were mentioned.
 Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
 <#5985 (comment)>,
 or mute the thread
 <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/ABtim0rbxiPCNfdmX3QipRXehOp8B-JSks5rtLO4gaJpZM4LAZNz>
 .
body:
@ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> are you passing the
sequence_length= argument to the static rnn call?

On Thu, Apr 6, 2017 at 2:43 AM, Vlad Firoiu <notifications@github.com>
wrote:

> @ankeshanand <https://github.com/ankeshanand> I think it might work in
> 0.10/0.11, but I don't remember for sure. I just ended up writing my own
> unroller:
>
> def rnn(cell, inputs, initial_state):
>   inputs = tf.unpack(inputs, axis=1)
>   outputs = []
>   state = initial_state
>   for input_ in inputs:
>     output, state = cell(input_, state)
>     outputs.append(output)
>   outputs = tf.pack(outputs, axis=1)
>   return outputs, state
>
> This assumes the time axis is 1. In more recent tensorflow versions,
> [un]pack has been renamed to [un]stack.
>
> —
